title: Compass’s ‘Chief Evangelist’ on the Importance of a Home’s Context
text:
As chief evangelist at Compass, Leonard Steinberg’s job is to promote the company’s culture, and provide tools to its team of brokers. He also offers his more than-two-decades of real estate expertise and knowledge to sellers, developers and buyers, and is responsible for over $3 billion in transactions.

We caught up with the South African-born, New York City-based Mr. Steinberg, 54, to discuss the importance of authenticity in real estate, why a home should feel collected, and more.

Mansion Global: Describe your dream property.

Leonard Steinberg: It would have light and large windows, but I don’t like all glass. Room dimension, scale and ceiling height matter. I like one or two rooms with extra-high ceiling height. I like a view. It can be an intimate look at a small lane or even a small garden; it doesn’t have to be Central Park. Most importantly, the quality of the space is critical.

Also, mechanicals that function well, especially in New York, where there are extremes of climate. Keeping the right temperature is a true luxury.

I’m a light sleeper, so I like a highly insulated home, and you can’t hear anything.

More: Sotheby’s International Realty’s Executive Says Customizing a Home is Key

MG: Do you have a real estate property that got away?

LS: I fall in love with practically every apartment I sell. We recently sold a penthouse in the village, and I’ve been in this business for 23 years, and it was the only one that I wanted to cry about when we sold.

MG: What does luxury mean to you?

LS: Luxury is different things to different people. It’s that which provides great comfort and a respite from your normal life, and it’s a place where you create the moments that matter. There’s something about a home that fuels the energy of your life. The home, and the setting and environment that it’s set in matter.

I always say time is the last luxury, so if you can find any time—whether from convenience or walkability, that matters.

And one of the great luxuries is beauty, but it’s different for everyone. It can fuel creativity and reduce stress.

More: Design Firm Chief Says Luxury is About Tapping Into All the Senses

MG: What area do you think is the next hub for luxury properties?

LS: Manhattan is becoming “neighborhood agnostic.” There are very few neighborhoods that don’t have luxury buildings. Also, Uber democratizes things.

MG: What’s the biggest surprise in the luxury real estate market now?

LS: How luxury interiors are becoming more like high-fashion— and trendier.

You need to be careful that what you design is not a pure self-indulgence, and that it lasts over time, and isn’t too taste-specific.

You don’t want things to look generic, but you want to have a home that feels collected.

From Penta: Good Company: Carol Chugani’s Sustainable and Multi-Functional Cashmere

MG: Where are the best luxury homes in the world and why?

LS: America does have amazing luxury homes. New York has some of the most beautiful ones, but they’re rare. Paris has always had exquisite real estate, but they don’t have the modern features. There’s beautiful real estate around the world—in Buenos Aires, Cape Town, Aspen, Montecito, Miami. There’s something to be found everywhere, but it takes a discerning eye to differentiate between good and great.

MG: What’s your favorite part of your home?

LS: My bedroom is like a gray and cream cloud. It feels protected. We have filtered fresh air, and the temperature is maintained beautifully. Aesthetically I don’t think it’s earth-shattering, but it’s calming, which, for me, is extremely valuable.

MG: What best describes the theme to your home and why?

LS: It has a collected aesthetic, made of things I’ve collected over the years, with the help of designer so it doesn’t look like a mess.

I wanted my home to be aware of its environment and setting. It doesn’t look like a sleek high-rise in Singapore, for example.

I think authenticity is often missing in real estate.

More: Luxury is About Inner Wellness, Says Los Angeles-Based Designer

MG: What’s the most valuable thing in your home?

LS: My art. It’s an eclectic mix. But I have a piece by Elger Esser—landscape scene in the south of France. In the middle of winter in New York, it transports you to the summer in France.

MG: What’s the most valuable amenity to have in a home right now?

LS: A gym. Helps wellbeing and health. I have one in my weekend house.

MG: What’s your best piece of real estate advice?

LS: To be wary of bargains and seek value in that which I call collector-quality elements—things that are not easily replicated.

If you’re coming to New York City, you want to have a New York City experience; if you’re going to Aspen, you want to have an Aspen experience; in Paris, it’s about having a Paris experience.

More: New York Real Estate Investor and Developer Says Despite Challenges, Manhattan’s Market is Still a Leader

MG: What’s going on in the news that will have the biggest impact on the luxury real estate market?

LS: We’re in a time of uncertainty and in the depths of great prosperity. These are the most prosperous times in U.S. history, but it’s chaotic.

The U.S.-China trade conflict is a big one. It seems to be a negative on everyone’s clarity/vision for the future.

There are lots of rumblings that we’re overdue for a correction in the real estate market, since we’ve been on an uptick in 10 years.

There’s something in between a global and a nationalist economy. At the moment, the extremes seem to be winning, but ultimately “glocalism” is the way to be.

There’s a wait-and-see attitude at the moment, despite low interest rates with available capital.

The luxury real estate buyer is always afraid of buying on a high and selling on a low.

More: Designer Andre Fu Says a Home Should Reflect Its Neighborhood

MG: What’s the best area for investing in luxury properties?

LS: Anywhere with good quality of life and anywhere with good jobs. Security is a big one, too.



Climate change makes a place’s current weather not matter as much. But as a result of climate change, you need self sufficiency too. Who knows what kind of storms there will be and what kinds of strains will be put on utility services?

MG: If you had a choice of living in a new development or a prime resale property, which would you choose and why?

LS: The last two apartments I’ve bought have all been in new buildings, the predominant reason being that I’ve been involved with them. I like modern mechanicals—an insulated apartment that’s energy efficient, sound efficient and has filtered fresh air.

More: Holistic Wellness is the Perk Buyers Really Want, Says NYC Brokerage Chief

MG: What area currently has the best resale value?

LS: There are always going to be the super-prime locations. People are always drawn toward the west, where the sun sets.

Globally, luxury navigates toward blue-chip areas. Only long-term speculators feel comfortable in other places. But if you want to invest, you want to look to tech hubs, such as Boston, Austin and New York. You see it in Los Angeles, San Francisco, even a little in Miami. You want to go wherever the jobs of the future are.
